entry.et: Middle English trien, from Anglo-French trier to select, sort, examine, determine, probably from Late Latin tritare to grind, frequentative of Latin terere to rub throw

def.dt: :to examine or investigate judicially try a case
:to conduct the trial of
:to participate as counsel in the judicial examination of
:to put to test or trial try one's luck often used with out try out a new method
:to subject to something (as undue strain or excessive hardship or provocation) that tests the powers of endurance
:demonstrate prove
:purify refine
:to melt down and procure in a pure state :render try out whale oil from blubber
:to fit or finish with accuracy
:to make an attempt at often used with an infinitive try to fix the car
:to make an attempt you can do it if you try
:to attempt something for the first time
:an experimental trial :attempt succeeded on the first try
:a play in rugby that is similar to a touchdown in football, scores usually five points, and entitles the scoring side to attempt a placekick at the goal for additional points
:the score made on a try
:an attempt made after scoring a touchdown in football to score one or two additional points by kicking the ball over the crossbar or again carrying it into the opponents' end zone
:to put on (a garment) in order to test the fit
:to use or test experimentally
:to compete for a position especially on an athletic team or for a part in a play
:a metallic pot used on a whaler or on shore to render whale oil from blubber
:an instrument consisting of two straightedges fixed at right angles to each other and used for laying off right angles and testing whether work is square

entry.et: from the phrase “give it the old college try”

def.dt: :a zealous all-out effort
:marked by trial and error cut–and–try methods cut–and–try testing
